2 B SUNDAY, APRIL 16, 1967
Mangers in Tax Support for TV
The Senate Commerce Committee
which currently is considering legis¬
lation to create a corporation to fi¬
nance noncommercial television with
tax funds is wrestling with the thorny
question of how to make sure that
financial support will not lead to
political control.
Noncommercial television potential¬
ly has a great future in this country.
If it is operated properly it can
present programs which are artistical¬
ly meritorious, even though they may
not appeal to the rating-set viewers
who somehow always seem to prefer
“Beverly Hillbillies’’ to, say, a concert
by the New York Philharmonic Or¬
chestra.
And good programming by non¬
commercial television might very well
include investigation in depth and
presentation of both sides of contro¬
versies that are too “hot” for com¬
mercial television with its sponsors
who are vitally interested in not mak¬
ing any of their potential customers
mad at them.
Now, suppose that instead of a com¬
mercial sponsor’s money, television
relied on tax funds for its support
and suppose that the programmers
decided to present a study showing
the plight of the tenant farmers in
the south, including a statement of
the views of Stokeley Carmichael. Or
a view of political ideologies, includ¬
ing a statement by Herbert Ap-
thecker. Or a program on the use of
narcotics at college campuses, includ¬
ing a statement bv a leader of
LFMar.
It is almost a foregone conclusion
that any such program would be fol¬
lowed immediately by outraged
speeches from senators and congress¬
men and private taxpayers about the
misuse of taxpayers’ money. And
the chances are pretty good that the
programmers would be hauled up
before one or more congressional
committee and harassed for present¬
ing that type of program.
No matter how strong the safe¬
guards, they wouldn’t stop dema¬
gogues from trying to make political
hay from controversial programming,
particularly when public funds were
involved. The end result could very
well be that noncommercial television
would wind up showing nothing more
penetrating than its own equivalent
of “Beverly Hillbillies.”
We are inclined to go along with
Fred W. Friendly, former head of the
CBS News Division, who said he
would be opposed to any system that
relied on general Treasury Depart¬
ment appropriations which would be
subject to annual reviews by Con¬
gress. He suggested instead that
news and public affairs programming
be underwritten from private funds,
preferably out of the savings that
might be realized by a nonprofit sys¬
tem of communications satellites.
We can only repeat what we said
last February in connection with the
creation of a state-operated television
network: “The inherent dangers are
obvious to anyone who gives it serious
consideration. And the fact that the
incursions are labeled ‘educational’
and that present intentions are com¬
pletely honorable does not in any
way lessen the potential danger.”
